AI_QUALITY_FAILURES.reasoning: Support provided incorrect root-cause guidance by treating the AppManager error as a license incompatibility and directing the customer to Customer Care, later contradicted by an internal note stating this is a known/expected post-migration behavior fixed by resetting the AppManager agent. This misdiagnosis likely prolonged resolution and created unnecessary handoffs. There are also signs of low-quality/unsafe content (e.g., odd/fake-looking email address in instructions).
evidence: Mike Kebede (public, 2025-10-27): "The issue is clearly with the license registration itself... the license file is still bound to the old hardware box's serial number and won't work properly on the new virtual appliance."
Mike Kebede (public, 2025-10-27): "Contact GFI Customer Care..." (customer sent away for a license rebind)

Mike Kebede (private, 2025-10-28): "The issue is misclassification of tickets where the error message... is mistakenly treated as a license issue... Resolution: Reset the AppManager agent — this is the only valid fix."
Mike Kebede (public, 2025-10-27): "Email address: hofman.500dced1d06a4f7aaba14e85e503de34@gfi.fake.ziva.cz"

AI_WALL_LOOPING.reasoning: The customer explicitly reports being bounced between channels (Customer Care → Atlas → Support → back to license/Customer Care), indicating a loop and difficulty reaching the right human team. The flow shows handoff to Customer Care even though the ultimate fix was a technical agent reset, reinforcing the 'ping-pong' experience.
evidence: Customer (2025-10-20 issue description): "customer care send me to Atlas! please make from conversation support request for technician"
Customer (2025-10-27): "I created ticket to this support before you and they saw that I have to create ticket on you and now back to license support. :("
Mike Kebede (public, 2025-10-27): "Contact GFI Customer Care"

IGNORING_CONTEXT.reasoning: Despite the customer confirming connectivity (DNS/HTTPS access to appmanager.gfi.com) and providing logs, support still concluded the problem was the license being bound to old hardware and redirected the customer to Customer Care. This indicates they did not appropriately incorporate the already-shared troubleshooting results and evidence into the diagnosis. Some uncertainty remains because they did review logs, but the final conclusion ignored key context and was later corrected internally.
evidence: Customer (2025-10-23): "problem still persist. I sent you log file... Unable to contact AppManager: appliance does not have valid license"
Customer (2025-10-23): "1. test DNS, ok... also from ssh terminal, lynx, curl.. open website appmanager.gfi.com ok"
Mike Kebede (public, 2025-10-27): "You've confirmed that DNS, outbound connectivity, and network access are all working properly. The issue is clearly with the license registration itself."
Mike Kebede (private, 2025-10-28): "misclassification... mistakenly treated as a license issue."

RESPONSE_DELAYS.reasoning: There is a noticeable gap where the customer follows up asking for a solution, suggesting waiting time between responses. The overall resolution time is also long (~7.9 days) per CSV, which supports the presence of delays even if not all were due to support inactivity.
evidence: Customer (2025-10-22): "Hello,do you have some solution for me?"
CSV: resolutionTime=687439
CSV: initialResponseTime=2539

PREMATURE_CLOSURE.reasoning: The ticket appears to have been resolved and then closed after the customer confirmed the fix worked. While agents used standard "ticket will stay open for one week unless..." language, there is no evidence it was closed while the customer still needed help.
evidence: Customer (2025-10-28): "your colleague solve this problem... Thank you"
CSV: Status=closed
CSV: Ticket Solved=2025-10-28 18:25:30
CSV: Ticket Closed=2025-10-31 18:35:25

P1_SEV1_MISHANDLING.reasoning: The case was flagged as a core functionality defect, and the customer could not register/validate the license during a hardware migration, which can be business-critical. Despite this, the issue was misdiagnosed and routed to Customer Care before the known technical fix (reset AppManager agent) was provided, likely extending downtime. Severity is not explicitly labeled P1/Sev1, so this is flagged with some uncertainty based on the stated severity and impact.
evidence: Centralsupport-ai-acc (private, 2025-10-20): "The severity is: core_functionality_defect"
